Yesurathnam | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | pronunciation = | birth_name = Regunta Yesurathnam | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1941|10|16}}R.Yesurathnam, ''A Christian Dialogical Theology: The Contribution of Swami Abhishiktananda'', Punthi Pustak, [[Calcutta]], 2006.[https://books.google.co.in/books?id=XU7ZAAAAMAAJ&dq=regunta+yesurathnam&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi83cevtsXVAhUFVbwKHdkRDM0Q6AEIJTAA] | birth_place = [[Nirmal]], [[Nirmal district]] (previously under [[Adilabad district]]), [[Telangana]], India | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2011|08|08|1941|10|16}} | death_place = [[Hyderabad]], [[Telangana]] | death_cause = [[Pneumonia]] | residence = | nationality = [[Indian people|India]] | education = [[Bachelor of Divinity|B. D.]] ([[Senate of Serampore College (University)|Serampore]]),K. M. Hiwale (Compiled), ''Directory of the [[United Theological College, Bangalore|United Theological College]] 1910–1997'', [[Bangalore]], 1998. Past students of the graduate course, p.33; Postgraduate course, p.106.; [[Doctor of Theology|D.Th.]], p.142.[https://books.google.co.in/books?id=yCvXPgAACAAJ&dq=Directory+of+the+United+Theological+College+1910%E2%80%931997&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwizvLv70dnVAhVIqY8KHfG9D9kQ6AEIJzAA]
[[Master of Arts|M. A.]] ([[Osmania University|Osmania]]),
[[Master of Theology|M. Th.]] ([[Senate of Serampore College (University)|Serampore]]),
[[Doctor of Theology|D. Th.]] ([[Senate of Serampore College (University)|Serampore]]) | alma_mater =[[United Theological College, Bangalore]] ([[Karnataka]]),
[[Selly Oak Colleges]], [[Birmingham]] (England) | occupation = [[Priesthood]] | years_active = 1967–2011 | parents = | website = | religion = [[Christianity]] | church = [[Church of South India]] | ordained = 1967, by [[Bishop]] [[Eber Priestley]] at the [[Church of South India|CSI]]-[[Medak Cathedral]], [[Medak]] | writings = ''See section on writings'' | congregations = [[Sangareddy]]R. Yesurathnam, ''The Cross of Christ as the Anchor of Hope in Suffering'', ''[[National Council of Churches Review]]'', Volume 123, 2003, pp.195-206.[https://books.google.co.in/books?id=7R3ZAAAAMAAJ&dq=The+Cross+of+Christ+as+the+Anchor+of+Hope+in+Suffering+yesurathnam&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=yesurathnam] and other towns under the ecclesiastical jurisdiction of the [[Diocese of Medak]] {{small|(1967-1974)}} | offices_held = Teacher - in - [[Systematic theology]],R. Yesurathnam, ''Book Review on Mission Today, Challenges and Responses'' in ''[[International Bulletin of Missionary Research]]'', Volume 3, Issue 136, July 1999, p.139.[http://www.internationalbulletin.org/issues/1999-03/1999-03-136-bookreviews.pdf] [[Andhra Christian Theological College]], [[Secunderabad]] (India) {{small|(1974-2001)}},
Principal, [[Andhra Christian Theological College]], [[Secunderabad]] (India) {{small|(1994-1998)}},
Guest Professor, [[:de:Kirchliche Hochschule Wuppertal/Bethel]] ([[Germany]]) {{small|(1993)}},
[[Council for World Mission|CWM]]-Missionary and Director, [[International University of the Caribbean]], [[Kingston, Jamaica|Kingston]] ([[Jamaica]]) {{small|(2001-2011)}} | title = The Reverend Doctor | signature = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} {{Portal|Methodism|Theology}} '''Regunta Yesurathnam''' (16 October 1941 – 8 August 2011)[[Senate of Serampore College (University)]], ''Minutes of the Eighty-sixth meeting of the [[Senate of Serampore College (University)]] held on 9 and 10 February 2012 at the New Theological College, [[Dehradun]]'', 2012. [http://www.senateofseramporecollege.edu.in/docs/senateminutes2012.pdf] was a [[priest]] hailing from the [[Diocese of Medak of the Church of South India]], headquartered in [[Medak]], notable as a [[Systematic theology|systematic theologian]]Charles E. Van Engen, ''Five Perspectives of Contextually Appropriate Missional Theology'' in Charles H. Kraft (Edited), ''Appropriate Christianity'', William Carey Library, Pasadena, 2005, p.194.[https://books.google.co.in/books?id=RysiXCZ7JJgC&pg=PA194] who served as Faculty Member from 1974 through 2001 in [[Secunderabad]], [[Telangana]], India, at the [[Andhra Christian Theological College]], affiliated to the [[Senate of Serampore College (University)]]. Yesurathnam has been acknowledged for his contribution to the disciplines of [[Interfaith dialogue|Dialogical Theology]] and [[Comparative religion]].T. Swami Raju, ''The Study of Religion: Methods of Perspectives'', BTESSC, SATHRI, Bangalore, 2004, p.54.[https://books.google.co.in/books?id=VpnXAAAAMAAJ&q=r.yesuratnam&dq=r.yesuratnam&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwio_IW4p-nVAhVKRo8KHXDtAXoQ6AEINTAE] As a pupil of another CSI systematic theologian, [[Joshua Russell Chandran]], under whom he was groomed in the 1960s, Yesurathnam established himself as a scholar and during the subsequent decade, as evidenced by his interest in Dialogical Theology, Yesurathnam seemed to have been influenced by the religious scholars [[Stanley Jedidiah Samartha]], of the [[Church of South India]] (CSI), Herbert Jai Singh, of the [[Methodist Church in India]] (MCI)Herbert Jai Singh, ''The Teaching of Religions in the Indian Context'', ''[[Indian Journal of Theology]]'', Volume 29, Numbers 3 and 4, July–December 1980, pp.149-159.[https://biblicalstudies.org.uk/pdf/ijt/29-3-4_149.pdf] and David C. Scott, also of the MCI. During the initial years of his doctoral research in the 1970s, it was [[Arvind P. Nirmal]], [[Church of North India|CNI]] (the proponent of [[Dalit theology]]) who supervised and enabled Yesurathnam to push through his doctoral studies. ==Contribution== ===Dialogical theology=== {{Main article|Interfaith dialogue}} Professor Jutta Sperber, of the [[University of Münster]], Germany, in a work about Dialogical Theology with special reference to the activities of the [[World Council of Churches]] and its unit on Dialogue, has quoted the work of Yesurathnam on the Christian-[[Muslim]] dialogue. Similarly, Sonia CalzaSonia Calza, ''La contemplazione: via privilegiata al dialogo cristiano-induista : Sulle orme di [[Jules Monchanin|J. Monchanin]], [[Henri Le Saux|H. Le Saux]], [[Raimon Panikkar|R. Panikkar]] e [[Bede Griffiths|B. Griffiths]]'', Pauline, Milan, 2001, p.359.[https://books.google.co.in/books?id=UDa57qubFoIC&lpg=PA165] while researching on interfaith dialogue with reference to [[Hinduism]] and Christianity, referred to Yesurathnam's work on Dialogical Theology while writing about the contribution of [[Henri Le Saux]].Catherine Cornille (Edited), ''The Wiley-Blackwell Companion to Inter-Religious Dialogue'', Wiley-Blackwell, 2013. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=UHdgFhRKCOsC&pg=PA1931] ===Comparative religion=== {{Main article|Comparative religion}} Yesurathnam, also wrote on the work on the concept of Avatara, which has been cited by other scholars. Bob RobinsonBob Robinson, ''Christians Meeting Hindus: An Analysis and Theological Critique of the Hindu-Christian Encounter in India'', Regnum, [[Oxford]], 2004, p.275.[https://books.google.co.in/books?id=jYsVCItO7tAC&pg=PR4] noted this work with special emphasis on the relationship to [[Christianity]] and Steven Tsoukalas quoted Yesurathnam's work on the forms of Avatara.Steven Tsoukalas, ''Krishna and Christ: Body-divine Relation in the Thought of [[Shiva|Sankara]], [[Ramanuja]] and Classical Christian Orthodoxy'', [[Paternoster Press|Paternoster]], [[Milton Keynes]], 2007, pp.23, 227, 240, 241.[https://books.google.co.in/books?id=djIlAQAAIAAJ&q=regunta+yesuratnam&dq=regunta+yesuratnam&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiGhNCvysXVAhXGMo8KHR9sDPkQ6AEIQzAG] ===Contextualization=== {{Main article|Contextualization (Bible translation)}} Inter-disciplinary writings by Yesurathnam have struck new ground in [[inculturation]] as espoused by [[Swamy Amalorananda]] and the [[New Testament]] Scholar [[Suppogu Joseph]], [[Samavesam of Telugu Baptist Churches|STBC]] (2007)[http://www.printsasia.it/book/adaptation-of-the-gospel-tradition-in-luke-suppogu-joseph-8184580029-9788184580020 S. Joseph, ''Adaptation of the Gospel Tradition in Luke'', ISPCK, 2007] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924081817/http://www.printsasia.it/book/adaptation-of-the-gospel-tradition-in-luke-suppogu-joseph-8184580029-9788184580020 |date=2015-09-24 }} had made a sustained research exploring possibilities for the [[Gospel]] to adapt itself to the multi-religious ethos of India. Earlier proponents who experimented with [[Contextualization (Bible translation)|Contextualization]], emphasizing on the presentation of [[Christ]] adapting to the [[Indian culture]], were [[Robert de Nobili]], [[Society of Jesus|SJ]], [[E. Stanley Jones]], [[Methodist Church in India|MCI]], and [[B. V. Subbamma]], [[Andhra Evangelical Lutheran Church|AELC]], who together were known for their contribution to the [[Christian Ashram Movement]] in India. Yesurathnam's definition of [[Contextualization (Bible translation)|Contextualization]] has been acknowledged by scholars as a resourceful addition. Charles E. Van Engen and Akintunde E. AkinadeAkintunde E. Akinade, ''The Crucible of Faith: Justice and Liberation in the work of Engelbert Mvent'' in ''Religions - A Scholarly Journal'', Issue 3, 2012, pp.107-116. [http://www.qscience.com/doi/pdf/10.5339/rels.2012.justice.17] refer to the word ''contextualization'' as defined by Yesurathnam. ===Renewal of the Church=== {{Main article|Church renewal}} Yesurathnam cautioned the Church against falling into traditionalism. During the Golden Jubilee of the founding of the [[Uniting church]], the CSI held in [[Chennai]] in 1997,John C. B. Webster, ''The Church of South India Golden Jubilee'' in ''[[International Bulletin of Missionary Research]]'', Volume 22, Number 2, 1998, pp.50-54.[http://www.internationalbulletin.org/issues/1998-02/1998-02-ibmr.pdf] Yesurathnam spoke on the ills befalling the Church in India, {{quotation|(Adapted) ''The church hierarchy of [[Bishop]]s, [[Presbyter]]s, [[Deacon]]s and [[Laity]] is turning into a [[Varna (Hinduism)|Chaturvarna system]], with the [[Laity]] and [[Women]] as the [[Shudras]], the bottom-most caste.''R. Yesurathnam, ''Liberation from Jubilee Perspective'' in ''South India Churchman'', July 1997, pp.7-8.[http://www.internationalbulletin.org/issues/1998-02/1998-02-ibmr.pdf]{{fv|date=May 2018}}}} Echoing the apprehensions by Yesurathnam, [[Stanley Jedidiah Samartha]] who was also present at the Jubilee in [[Chennai]], pointed out that one must first introspect before raising [[cudgels]] against the [[Indian caste system]] and believed that one failed to notice the gradual transformation of the [[episcopacy]] into such a system.[[Stanley Jedidiah Samartha]], "Vision and Reality: Reflections on the Church of South India" in ''[[People's Reporter]]'', 1–15 September 1997, p.4. Yesurathnam, in an introduction to the book ''Jesus' Tears!'' by Elizabeth Thelma Johnson (2007),Elizabeth Thelma Johnson, ''Jesus' Tears!'', ISPCK, New Delhi, 2007, p.xv. [https://books.google.co.in/books?id=nlbUf3gPPl0C&lpg=PR15&dq=r.yesuratnam&pg=PR4#v=onepage&q&f=false] has highlighted the work of a [[Laity]] and appreciated their contribution towards the [[Christian missions]]. ==Studies== From his youth, Yesurathnam was inspired by the work of the [[Roman Catholic missionaries|Roman Catholic]] and [[Protestant missionary|Protestant]] [[Christian mission]]s in Telangana. He entered the ministry of the [[Catholic Church]] through the [[Diocese of Medak]], becoming a ministerial candidate during the bishopric of [[Frank Whittaker]], the first Bishop-in-Medak. He studied at a [[seminary]] in [[Bangalore]] for spiritual formation and was ordained in 1967 by [[Bishop]] [[Eber Priestley]], the then Bishop-in-Medak.{{cn|date=May 2018}} ===Graduate=== After initial schooling at the mission schools founded by the [[English Wesleyan Mission|Wesleyan Methodist Missionary Society]] (WMMS) in Telangana, Yesurathnam decided to take up [[priesthood]]. Bishops [[Frank Whittaker]] and [[Eber Priestley]], successively, became his Spiritual Confessors and led him to take up spiritual studies at the [[United Theological College, Bangalore]] during 1963-1967. He was awarded a [[Bachelor of Divinity|B. D.]] degree.{{cn|date=May 2018}} ===Postgraduate=== {{Main article|Pierre Teilhard de Chardin}} In 1969, Yesurathnam was recalled from parish work and sent to the Protestant Regional Theologiate in [[Bangalore]] for further spiritual studies that lasted until 1972 and resulted in the award of a [[Master of Theology]] degree after research under [[Joshua Russell Chandran]] of the CSI. ===Doctoral=== {{Main article|Henri Le Saux}} [[File:Swami Abhishiktananda.jpg|thumb|150px|left|[[Henri Le Saux]], [[Order of Saint Benedict|OSB]] (1910-1973) ([[Swami Abhishiktananda]]); Yesurathnam researched during 1978-1982 on [[Benedictine monk|Benedictine monk's]] experiences of [[spirituality]] as found in [[Hinduism]] and [[Christianity]]]] After a five-year teaching ministry that began in 1974 at the Andhra Christian Theological College, Secunderabad, Yesurathnam qualified to undertake doctoral level research in 1978 and was granted a five-year study leave.R. Yesurathnam, ''Religious Pluralism: Some Implications for the Mission of the Church'' in [[H. S. Wilson]] (Edited), ''The Church on the Move: A Quest to Affirm the Biblical Faith'', Christian Literature Society, Chennai, 1988.[https://books.google.co.in/books?id=S-wrAAAAMAAJ&q=h.+s.+wilson+victor+premasagar&dq=h.+s.+wilson+victor+premasagar&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjF3fKC7NnVAhVMrY8KHVgyCyMQ6AEIJzAA] Yesurathnam's Bishop during that period, [[B. G. Prasada Rao]], made efforts to ensure that Yesurathnam was able to join his ''[[alma mater]]'', the United Theological College, Bangalore, where he was able to take up research in the discipline of systematic theology under the guidance of Arvind P. Nirmal, [[Church of North India|CNI]]. Yesurathnam also came under the tutelage of [[Stanley Jedidiah Samartha]], a leading authority on Dialogical Theology.Hans Schwarz, ''Theology in a Global Context: The Last Two Hundred Years'', William B. Eerdmans, [[Grand Rapids]], 2005. pp.523-526. [https://books.google.com/books?id=gtkvQxB-6lsC&pg=PA524] During the research period between 1978-1982, Yesurathnam was also sent to the [[University of Birmingham]], England, in 1979 for a two-year research exposure through the efforts of Gordon Shaw who ensured his overseas travel and stay in England at Kingsmead College under the [[Selly Oak Colleges]], where he was supervised by [[Walter Jacob Hollenweger]], a leading authority on [[Pentecostalism]].[[Walter Jacob Hollenweger]], ''My Pilgrimage in Mission'', ''[[International Bulletin of Missionary Research]]'', Volume 29, Number 2, 2005, p. 85-88.[http://www.wjhollenweger.ch/files/2005-02-085-hollenweger-my-pilgrimage-in-mission.pdf] By 1981, Yesurathnam returned to the United Theological College and began shaping his doctoral dissertation under the guidance of David C. Scott and by 1982, he rejoined the Andhra Christian Theological College, which by then was being led by the [[New Testament]] scholar,David Komaravalli, ''Divine Operation and Human Response: A Comparison Between [[Rudolf Bultmann]]'s Understanding of the Pauline Perspectives and Certain Elements in Recent Indian Thought'', [[University of Edinburgh]], [[Edinburgh]], 1973.[https://books.google.co.in/books?id=Iq8UMwEACAAJ&dq=komaravalli+david&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjW3abo_f_VAhXMvY8KHTj8AoEQ6AEIJzAA] K. David, [[CBCNC]][[Mar Aprem Mooken]], ''Indian Christian who is who'', Bombay Parish Church of the East, Bombay, 1983, p.106.[https://books.google.co.in/books?id=u2s5AAAAMAAJ&q=komaravalli+david&dq=komaravalli+david&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjW3abo_f_VAhXMvY8KHTj8AoEQ6AEIMDAC] and took up his teaching role in systematic theology, but was able to submit his doctoral thesis to the university through his supervisor at the United Theological College and finally in 1987, much before nearing a decade of registering with the university, it awarded the degree of [[Doctor of Theology]].Senate of Serampore College, ''List of the Recipient of the Degree of Doctor of Theology''. [http://www.senateofseramporecollege.edu.in/hall-of-fame/doctor-of-theology/] Though Yesurathnam sought permission from the Senate of Serampore College to publish his doctoral work nearly two decades later, in 2006. His thesis was already being referred by research scholarsAntony Kalliath, ''The Word in the Cave: The Experiential Journey of Swami Abhishiktānanda to the Point of Hindu-Christian Meeting'', Intercultural Publications, New Delhi, 1996, p.436.[https://books.google.co.in/books?id=tgPkAAAAMAAJ&q=antony+kalliath+dialogical+theology&dq=antony+kalliath+dialogical+theology&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjLnIur8f_VAhUBOY8KHXaEBUkQ6AEILDAB] on works relating to the contribution of [[Swami Abhishiktananda]]. ==Ministry== ===Pastoral ministry=== [[File:Medakcathedralsideview.png|thumb|right|200px|The [[Church of South India|CSI]]-Medak Cathedral,[[Medak]] where Yesurathnam was ordained in 1967 by Bishop [[Eber Priestley]], [[Diocese of Medak|Bishop - in - Medak]].]] {{Main article|Diocese of Medak of the Church of South India}} Yesurathnam was ordained in 1967 by Priestley, then Bishop-in-Medak, and was assigned ministerial functions in the parishes falling under the ecclesiastical jurisdiction of the Diocese of Medak and served in [[Sangareddy]] and other towns shepherding congregations for nearly a decade until he was recalled in 1974 by then Bishop, [[H. D. L. Abraham]], and reassigned the role of a Spiritual Formator.{{cn|date=May 2018}} In 1992, when [[Victor Premasagar]] vacated the bishopric of Medak on attaining superannuation, the ensuing [[Sede vacante]] was contested among whom Yesurathnam stood in the fray for the vacant bishopric, which was overseen by [[Ryder Devapriam]], then Moderator of the [[Church of South India Synod]] and a former colleague of Yesurathnam at the Protestant Regional Theologiate. However, the sudden death of Devapriam on 4 September 1992[http://dioceseofnandyal.org/ Diocese of Nandyal] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100106141716/http://dioceseofnandyal.org/ |date=2010-01-06 }} while in [[Germany]]''[[National Council of Churches Review]]'', Volume 112, 1992, p.774.[https://books.google.co.in/books?id=MgnZAAAAMAAJ&q=ryder+devapriam+germany&dq=ryder+devapriam+germany&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwixraOg4eHXAhWBv48KHfPuDxgQ6AEIJTAA] turned the tides for those in fray, resulting in the appointment and subsequent consecration of [[B. P. Sugandhar]]. ===Teaching=== The Andhra Christian Theological College (ACTC) relocated from [[Rajahmundry]] to Secunderabad. Yesurathnam was invited to join the college in 1974, during the Principalship of [[Victor Premasagar]].William Gordon Carder, ''On theological education in [[Andhra Pradesh]] of the [[Canadian Baptist Mission]] [[Convention of Baptist Churches of Northern Circars]] 1880-1975'' in ''Indian Church History Review'', Volume 13, Issue 1, 1979, pp.70-84.[https://books.google.co.in/books?id=wsTYAAAAMAAJ&dq=Christian+Ministerial+Training+in+the+Convention+of+Baptist+Churches+of+Northern+Circars+from+1882+to+1971&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=jeremiah] In 1993 he was appointed guest professor at the [[Kirchliche Hochschule Wuppertal/Bethel]] in Germany,Matthias Freudenberg, ''Anniversary letter to [[Jürgen Fangmeier]]'', 2011, p.6.[http://www.reformiert-info.de/daten/File/Upload/doc-10788-1.pdf] where he taught until 1994.{{cn|date=May 2018}} He then returned to ACTC and was appointed principal under the institution's policy of rotating that office between the various constituent churches in four-year cycles.{{cn|date=May 2018}} Yesurathnam took a year's sabbatical leave in 1998 to the Overseas Ministries Study Center, [[New Haven, Connecticut]] to continue his research pursuitsR. Yesurathnam, ''Book Review: Relevant Patterns of Christian Witness in India: People as Agents of Mission'', [[International Bulletin of Missionary Research]], Volume 25, Issue 88, 2001. [http://www.internationalbulletin.org/issues/2004-04/2004-04-191-index.pdf] and rejoined the Theologiate in Secunderabad to teach for two more years until 2001.{{cn|date=May 2018}} ===Missionary service=== When the [[Council for World Mission]] (CWM) sought missionaries from the CSI, Yesurathnam moved to the [[International University of the Caribbean]], [[Kingston, Jamaica]], where he began his sojourn in the [[New millennium]] and served as a theological educator for nearly a decade[[Council for World Mission]] Annual Review 2009'', ''Missionaries serving with CWM, 2009, pp. 18, 23.[http://www.cwmission.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/AnnualReport2009.pdf] until his death on 8 August 2011 at the [[Yashoda Hospitals]], [[Hyderabad]]. ==Writings== Yesurathnam's works are available in nearly 35 [[research institute]]s, comprising seminaries, [[State university (India)|state universities]] and research academies across Asia, Australia, Europe, and North America.[[WorldCat]] search on "Regunta Yesurathnam".[https://www.worldcat.org/title/christian-dialogical-theology-the-contribution-of-swami-abhishiktananda/oclc/607753147&referer=brief_results] *1972, ''[[Pierre Teilhard de Chardin]]'s concept of man and its relevance for a Christian interpretation of man in India'' *1987, ''The adequacy of the concept of Avatara for expounding the Christian doctrine of incarnation'' *1987, ''The Mythic Symbol Avatara in Indian Conceptual Formulations'' *1988, ''Religious Pluralism: Some Implications for the Mission of the Church'' *1990, ''Abhishiktānanda : An Indian Christian Theologian with a difference'' *1993, ''Contours of the emerging Indian Church: Problems and Possibilities'' *1998, ''Liberation from Jubilee Perspective'' *1999, ''Can the Clergy make it ?'' *1999, ''Book Review: Mission Today, Challenges and Responses'' *2000, ''Contextualizing in Mission'' *2001, ''Book Review: Relevant Patterns of Christian Witness in India: People as Agents of Mission'' *2001, ''Channels of Peace: A Theological Perspective'' *2003, ''The Cross of Christ as the Anchor of Hope in Suffering'' *2006, ''A Christian Dialogical Theology: The Contribution of Swami Abhishiktananda (Henri Le Saux)'' ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite journal | author=Robert North, [[Society of Jesus|S.J.]] (Compiled) | title=Elenchus of Biblica | year=1987 | volume=3 | issue= | issn=1123-5608| url =https://books.google.co.in/books?id=Dd6Gs13me0sC&lpg=PA544&ots=R4sQUAfZGt&dq=elenchus%20of%20biblica%20regunta%20yesurathnam&pg=PA544#v=onepage&q=elenchus%20of%20biblica%20regunta%20yesurathnam&f=false {{Refimprove|date=August 2017}}
The relationship between '''religion and [[HIV/AIDS]]''' is complicated, and often controversial. Controversies have mainly revolved around [[LGBT]] people and [[condom]] use.
==Religious attitudes towards HIV-positive people and AIDS== ===Islam===
The question of Islam and [[AIDS]] has arisen in recent years as the [[HIV/AIDS]] epidemic has grown stronger, with awareness and efforts to prevent the spread of the disease.<ref name="Tackling AIDS">{{cite web|url=http://www.islamonline.net/servlet/Satellite?c=Article_C&cid=1157962465531&pagename=Zone-English-HealthScience%2FHSELayout |title=Tackling AIDS Through Islam? |author=Najma Mohamed |work=Islam Online |accessdate=26 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070529085511/http://www.islamonline.net/servlet/Satellite?c=Article_C&cid=1157962465531&pagename=Zone-English-HealthScience%2FHSELayout |archivedate=May 29, 2007 }}</ref> Many Muslims view the AIDS epidemic through what is called the “prism of sin”, and as the consequence of sinful behavior, such as [[prostitution]], sex with multiple partners or [[promiscuity]].<ref name="Tackling AIDS"/> Awareness of the HIV/AIDS epidemic is growing among the Muslim community and efforts are being initiated to prevent its spread. The Muslim Awareness Programme (MAP), based in South Africa is a faith-based organization that promotes HIV/AIDS prevention strategies based on the moral teachings of Islam. These activities include the promotion of [[abstinence]] from all sexual activity outside marriage; refraining from drug use, and instilling faithfulness within marriage. According to most Muslims, the key to combating to the HIV/AIDS epidemic is prevention.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} In their view, the Islamic position on morality, chastity and the sanctity of marriage needs to be shared with the world. Islam cites sex with multiple partners, sex outside marriage, other promiscuous sexual behaviors and [[homosexuality]] as immoral and as a result of this some Muslims consider this behavior the main cause of HIV/AIDS, believing that promoting abstinence, chastity, and intramarital sex is the key to ending or at least containing the epidemic.
===Judaism and Jewish thinkers=== As opposed to the Catholic Church and some other denominations or religions, today, there isn't any central Jewish religious authority that is acceptable by vast majority of religious Jews or by most Jewish religious movements.
[[Orthodox Judaism]] links between immoral sexual behavior and AIDS. [[Immanuel Jakobovits, Baron Jakobovits]], former Chief Rabbi of England, a prominent figure in 20th century Jewish medical ethics<ref>[[Immanuel Jakobovits, Baron Jakobovits]]</ref> maintains in his article "Halachic Perspectives on AIDS" that "... from my reading of Jewish sources, it would appear that under no circumstances would we be justified in branding the incidence of the disease (...) as punishment ... we have not the vision, that would enable us to link, as an assertion of certainty, any form of human travail, grief, bereavement or suffering in general with shortcomings of a moral nature... It is one thing to speak of a consequence, and it is quite another thing to speak of a punishment ... if you warn a child not to play with fire, lest he gets burnt, and the child then gets burnt, then the burning may not be a punishment for not listening, but it certainly is a consequence. ... I think we should declare in very plain and explicit terms indicating that our society violated some of the norms of the Divine Law, and of the natural law, and that as a consequence we pay a price, and an exceedingly heavy price. This certainly is Jewish doctrine ..."<ref>[http://www.medethics.org.il/articles/JME/JMEB2/JMEB2.14.asp] ASSIA – ''Jewish Medical Ethics'', Vol. 2, No. 1, January 1991, pp. 3–8</ref>
In [[Jewish Orthodox]] society, having AIDS is considered a mark of disgrace.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jewish Responses to HIV: A Mitzvah|url=http://www.thebody.com/content/art56481.html|work=TheBody.com|accessdate=27 January 2014|author=Alana Krivo-Kaufman}}</ref>
[[Conservative Judaism|Conservative]] and [[Reform Judaism]] emphasize the importance of ''[[bikur cholim]]'', the responsibility to care for the sick: :"The [[United Synagogue of Conservative Judaism]] calls upon all of its congregations to reach out to individuals infected with the AIDS virus, their families and their friends by providing acceptance, comfort, counseling, and sympathetic and empathetic listening; and ... affirms that those infected with the AIDS virus must be protected from all forms of [[Discrimination against people with HIV/AIDS|illegal discrimination]], such as discriminatory housing, employment, health care delivery services and synagogue services."<ref>{{cite web|title=United Synagogue Resolution On AIDS|url=http://www.jewishlasvegas.com/page.aspx?id=12085|publisher=The Jewish Federation of Las Vegas|accessdate=27 June 2013|author=United Synagogue of Conservative Judaism|year=1991 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110920230253/http://www.jewishlasvegas.com/page.aspx?id=12085 |archivedate=20 September 2011}}</ref> Rabbi Marla J. Feldman, Director of the Joint Commission on Social Action of the Union for Reform Judaism: "However, we must look past the incomprehensible statistics and long lists of facts and recognize the Divine image within the faces of the individual people infected and affected by this disease. The responsibility lies with each of us to protect and care for these victims ..."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rac.org/Articles/index.cfm?id=1999&pge_prg_id=13740 |publisher=Religious Action Center of Reform Judaism|title=Reform Jewish Leader Mourns AIDS Deaths and Calls for Comprehensive HIV/AIDS Prevention |accessdate=April 20, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101127211945/http://rac.org/Articles/index.cfm?id=1999&pge_prg_id=13740 |archivedate=27 November 2010}}</ref>
=== Christianity === Many Christian charities provide services for people living with HIV/AIDS.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} One example is the [[DREAM (AIDS therapy program)|"Drug Resources Enhancement against Aids and Malnutrition" (DREAM)]], program promoted by the [[Christian]] [[Community of Sant'Egidio]].
[[Jerry Falwell]] regularly linked the [[AIDS pandemic]] to LGBT issues and stated, "AIDS is not just God's punishment for homosexuals, it is God's punishment for the society that tolerates homosexuals."<ref name="Falwell">{{cite web|url = http://www.milforddailynews.com/opinion/x1987843539|title=Press: The Sad Legacy of Jerry Falwell|accessdate=2007-05-18|last= Press|first = Bill |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080430144811/http://www.milforddailynews.com/opinion/x1987843539 |archivedate=30 April 2008}}</ref>
=== Hinduism === [[Hinduism]] has shown support for research aimed at curing HIV/AIDS, and care for those affected by HIV/AIDS.<ref name="Tackling AIDS"/>
==Prevention== ===Catholicism=== {{main|Catholic Church and AIDS}} The Catholic Church opposes [[condom]] use between heterosexual couples because it is an artificial form of [[contraception]] that does not rely on the functions of the body (and thus also God's will) itself as to whether a conception will occur or not, and the Church believes it also serves to implicitly and inexcusably encourage premarital and extramarital sexuality (and recourse to abortion if the condom fails).{{citation needed|date=August 2017}}
[[Pope John Paul II]] strongly opposed the use of artificial birth control, and rejected the use of condoms to prevent the spread of HIV.<ref name="John Paul II and condoms">{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,1979145,00.html|title=Catholic Church to Ease Ban on Condom Use|date=24 April 2006|publisher=© 2006, 2009 Deutsche Welle|accessdate=12 January 2009}}</ref> [[Pope Benedict XVI]] stated in 2005 that condoms were not a sufficient solution to the AIDS crisis,<ref>{{cite news|publisher=BBC News|title=Pope rejects condoms for Africa|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4081276.stm | date=2005-06-10 | accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref> but then in 2009 claimed that AIDS "cannot be overcome through the distribution of condoms, which even aggravates the problems."<ref>{{cite news|publisher=The Telegraph|title=Pope Benedict XVI: condoms make Aids crisis worse|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/vaticancityandholysee/5005357/Pope-Benedict-XVI-condoms-make-Aids-crisis-worse.html | date=2009-03-17 | accessdate=2011-05-22}}</ref> The [[Moscow Patriarchate]] gave support to Benedict XVI's position.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.catholic.org/news/international/africa/story.php?id=32756 |title=Moscow Patriarchate Backs Pope's Stance on Condoms |publisher=Zenit News Agency |date=21 March 2009}}</ref> In response to Benedict XVI's statements, the [[United Church of Christ]] issued a statement encouraging condom distribution at places of worship.<ref name="UCC and condoms">[http://www.ucc.org/news/uccs-health-advocates-press.html UCC’s health advocates press for increased condom distribution]</ref>
On November 20, 2010, when questioned about the rampant HIV spread in Africa, [[Pope Benedict XVI]] suggested that the use of condoms in male prostitution is not a moral solution to stopping AIDS, but could represent a first step in assuming moral responsibility "in the intention of reducing the risk of infection."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20101120/ap_on_re_eu/eu_pope_condoms |title=Pope says some condom use first step of morality |website=Yahoo News |publisher=Associated Press |date=20 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101121121202/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20101120/ap_on_re_eu/eu_pope_condoms |archivedate=21 November 2010}}</ref> Vatican City clarifies, after Benedict's statement sows confusion, that the position of the Church on condoms has not changed. It is merely a statement that in homosexual relations, where unnatural contraception is not the main concern, condoms can be seen as moral responsibility in preventing HIV infections.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/religion/2010-11-20-pope-condoms_N.htm | work=USA Today | title=Vatican clarifies pope's condom comments: Nothing's changed | date=2010-11-23}}</ref> On November 23, 2010, Benedict furthermore stated that the concept of condoms as a lesser evil in preventing HIV infections can be applied to women as well. The use of condoms is the first step in taking responsibility and attempting to prevent the infection of one's partner. The Pope does not say anything about condoms being acceptable as unnatural birth control, only as a responsible approach.<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/40331930/ns/world_news-europe]</ref>
===Buddhism=== In Thailand, some Buddhist monks encourage the use of condoms for HIV prevention.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buddhistchannel.tv/index.php?id=52,3702,0,0,1,0|title=Buddhist Monk Embraces Condoms|date=2007-02-07|accessdate=2009-10-25}}</ref> As part of [[Mechai Viravaidya]]'s pro-condom campaign, Buddhist monks have offered blessed condoms for couples.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/rxforsurvival/series/champions/mechai_viravaidya.html|publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]]|title = Global Health Champions: Mechai Viravaidya|accessdate=2009-10-25}}</ref>
==Treatment== The work of some Christian ministries has affected the treatment of AIDS. According to the African Health Policy Network, some churches in [[London]] claim that prayer will cure AIDS and the [[London Borough of Hackney|Hackney]]-based Centre for the Study of Sexual Health and HIV reports that several people have stopped taking their medication, sometimes on the direct advice of their [[pastor]], leading to a number of deaths.<ref name=BBC18102011>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-14406818|title=Church HIV prayer cure claims 'cause three deaths'|date=18 October 2011|accessdate=18 October 2011|publisher=[[BBC News]]}}</ref> The [[Synagogue Church Of All Nations]] advertise an "anointing water" to promote God's healing, although the group deny advising people to stop taking medication,<ref name=BBC18102011 /> and US [[patent application]] 2001051133 similarly suggests that intravenous pure distilled water will eradicate HIV through the mercy of God.<ref>{{Cite patent|US|2001051133|status=application}}</ref> Other Christian churches actively distribute HIV/AIDS medication.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

One of the most common ways that people cope with trauma is through the comfort found in religious or spiritual practices.<ref>Pargament, K. I. (1997). The psychology of religion and coping: Theory, research, practice. New York: Guilford Press.</ref> Psychologists of religion have performed multiple studies to measure the positive and negative effects of this coping style.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Trevino | first1 = K. M. | last2 = Pargament | first2 = K. I. | year = 2007 | title = Religious coping with terrorism and natural disaster | url = | journal = Southern Medical Journal | volume = 100 | issue = 9| pages = 946–947 | doi=10.1097/smj.0b013e3181454660| pmid = 17902314 }}</ref> Leading researchers have split religious coping into two categories: positive religious coping and negative religious coping. Individuals who use positive religious coping are likely to seek spiritual support and look for meaning in a traumatic situation. Negative religious coping (or [[spiritual struggle]]s) expresses conflict, question, and doubt regarding issues of God and faith.
The effects of religious coping are measured in many different circumstances, each with different outcomes. Some common experiences where people use religious coping are fear-inflicting events such as 9/11 or the holocaust, death and sickness, and near death experiences. Research also shows that people also use religious coping to deal with everyday stressors in addition to life-changing traumas. The underlying assumption of the ability of religion to influence the coping process lies in the hypothesis that religion is more than a [[defence mechanism]] as it was viewed by [[Sigmund Freud]]. Rather than inspiring denial, religion stimulates reinterpretations of negative events through the sacred lens.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Krok|first1=D|title=The mediating role of coping in the relationships between religiousness and mental health (2014)|publisher=Archives of Psychiatry and Psychotherapy}}</ref>
==Styles of religious coping== [[Kenneth Pargament]] is the author of the book ''[[Psychology of Religion and Coping]]'' and a leading researcher in religious coping. Along with developing the "RCOPE" questionnaire to measure religious coping strategies,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Pargament | first1 = Kenneth I. | last2 = Koenig | first2 = Harold G. | last3 = Perez | first3 = Lisa M. | year = 2000 | title = The many methods of religious coping: Development and initial validation of the RCOPE | url = | journal = Journal of Clinical Psychology | volume = 56 | issue = 4| pages = 519–543 | doi = 10.1002/(SICI)1097-4679(200004)56:4<519::AID-JCLP6>3.0.CO;2-1 | pmid = 10775045 }}</ref> Pargament and his colleagues designated three basic styles of coping with stress.<ref>Kenneth I. Pargament, Joseph Kennell, William Hathaway, Nancy Grevengoed, Jon Newman & Wendy Jones (1988). Religion and the problem-solving process: Three styles of coping. Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion, v27 n1, pp90-104. ISSN 0021-8294</ref> In Pargament's article "Religion and the Problem-Solving Process: Three Styles of Coping", he identifies the collaborative, self-directed, and deferring coping styles. The collaborative style of religious coping involves an active and internalized personal exchange with God. The deferring coping style is when individuals rely heavily on God and delegate their stress without taking personal responsibility for the situation. The self-directed style of religious coping emphasizes the free will given by God that allows for the individual to solve the problem on their own. The collaborative style of coping has been found to produce the most advantages in clinical settings.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Phillips | first1 = III | last2 = Lynn | first2 = Q. K. | last3 = Crossley | first3 = C. D. | last4 = Pargament | first4 = K. I. | year = 2004 | title = Self-Directing Religious Coping: A Deistic God, Abandoning God, or No God at All? | url = | journal = Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion | volume = 43 | issue = 3| pages = 409–418 | doi=10.1111/j.1468-5906.2004.00243.x}}</ref>
In a meta-analysis of 49 studies reviewing religion as a coping method, several mechanisms of positive coping were identified. Several are listed below. * religious purification/forgiveness * religious direction/conversion * seeking support from clergy members * spiritual connection In the same study, negative coping strategies were also pinpointed. Some of them are listed below. * spiritual discontent * punishing God reappraisal * reappraisal of God's powers * pleading for direct intercession The study then identified forms of positive psychological adjustment, like those listed below. * acceptance * happiness * optimism * purpose in life A similar list of negative psychological adjustments was compiled. * anxiety * burden * negative mood * callousness Positive religious coping methods correlated more strongly with positive psychological adjustment than negative psychological adjustment. Similarly, negative religious coping methods correlated with negative psychological adjustment.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ano|first1=Gene|last2=Vasconcelles|first2=Erin|title=Religious Coping and Psychological Adjustment to Stress: A Meta-Analysis|journal=Journal of Clinical Psychology|date=2005|volume=61|issue=4|pages=461–80|doi=10.1002/jclp.20049|pmid=15503316}}</ref>
==Specific traumatic events==
===September 11 attacks=== The [[September 11 attacks]] have been widely studied among psychologists. Research has shown that 90% of Americans coped with the stress of September 11 (2001) by "turning to religion".<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Koenig|first1=Harold G|title=Research on Religion, Spirituality, and Mental Health: A Review|journal=The Canadian Journal of Psychiatry|volume=54|issue=5|pages=283–291|doi=10.1177/070674370905400502|pmid=19497160|year=2009}}</ref> Sixty-two percent of a sample of undergraduate and graduate students reported praying to cope with the stress that followed the attacks.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Stein | first1 = BD | last2 = Elliott | first2 = MN | last3 = Jaycox | first3 = LH | display-authors = etal | year = 2004 | title = A national longitudinal study of the psychological consequences of the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks: reactions, impairment, and help-seeking | url = | journal = Psychiatry | volume = 67 | issue = 2| pages = 105–117 | doi=10.1521/psyc.67.2.105.35964| pmid = 15262576 }}</ref> Further analysis showed that searching for spiritual meaning was associated with less anxiety and depression.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Ai | first1 = AL | last2 = Cascio | first2 = T | last3 = Santangelo | first3 = LK | display-authors = etal | year = 2005 | title = Hope, meaning, and growth following the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks | url = | journal = J Interpers Violence | volume = 20 | issue = 5| pages = 523–548 | doi=10.1177/0886260504272896| pmid = 15788553 }}</ref> Psychologists also examined the types of coping used and how they affected mental health outcomes. Research shows that people who used positive religious coping displayed greater optimism, less anxiety, and higher levels of positive emotion three months after the attacks.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Ai | first1 = AL | last2 = Tice | first2 = TN | last3 = Peterson | first3 = C | display-authors = etal | year = 2005 | title = Prayers, spiritual support, and positive attitudes in coping with the September 11 national crisis | url = | journal = J Pers | volume = 73 | issue = 3| pages = 763–791 | doi=10.1111/j.1467-6494.2005.00328.x| pmid = 15854013 }}</ref> Individuals who used positive religious coping were found to have significantly more positive outcomes (closeness with God, relationships with family and friends) than those who used negative religious coping.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Pargament | first1 = KI | last2 = Ishler | first2 = K | last3 = Dubow | first3 = EF | display-authors = etal | year = 1994 | title = Methods of religious coping with the Gulf War: Cross-sectional and longitudinal analyses | url = | journal = J Sci Study Relig | volume = 33 | issue = 4| pages = 347–361 | doi=10.2307/1386494| jstor = 1386494 }}</ref> American Muslims were another highly studied group after the attacks. Results in this area align with previous research, showing that positive religious coping is associated with posttraumatic growth, while negative religious coping predicted higher levels of depression and anxiety.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Abu-Raiya | first1 = H. | last2 = Pargament | first2 = K. I. | last3 = Mahoney | first3 = A. | year = 2010 | title = Examining coping methods with stressful interpersonal events experienced by Muslims living in the United States following the 9/11 attacks | url = | journal = Psychology of Religion and Spirituality | volume = 3| issue = | pages = 1–14| doi = 10.1037/a0020034 }}</ref>
===Death of a loved one===
Individuals deal with the death of significant people in their lives in a variety of ways. One of the most common ways that Americans deal with the death of a loved one is by turning to religion. Although most psychologists would argue that religious coping leads to positive outcomes, some research identifies that coping using religious can lead to greater amounts of distress, especially in dealing with the loss of a family member due to homicide.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Thompson | first1 = M. P. | last2 = Vardaman | first2 = P. J. | year = 1997 | title = The role of religion in coping with the loss of a family member to homicide | url = | journal = Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion | volume = 36 | issue = 1| pages = 44–51 | doi = 10.2307/1387881 | jstor = 1387881 }}</ref> Further research recognized that the role of attachment to God is very important in determining how successful religious coping will be.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Ungureanu | first1 = I. | last2 = Sandberg | first2 = J. G. | year = 2010 | title = Broken together": Spirituality and religion as coping strategies for couples dealing with the death of a child: A literature review with clinical implications | url = | journal = Contemporary Family Therapy: An International Journal | volume = 32 | issue = 3| pages = 302–319 | doi = 10.1007/s10591-010-9120-8 }}</ref> Research shows that secure attachment to God and a positive religious coping style is positively correlated with stress related growth, positive religious outcomes, and a developed sense of meaning. Anxious and avoidant attachments to God and negative religious coping styles were positively correlated with depression, traumatic distress, and separation distress. Furthermore, attachment to God was strongly more correlated to positive outcomes than attachment to others.<ref>Kelley, M. M. (2003, April). Bereavement and grief related to a significant death: A psychological and theological study of attachment styles and religious coping. Dissertation Abstracts International Section A, 63,</ref>
===Near-death experiences===
[[Near-death experiences]] (NDEs) provide a unique opportunity for psychologists to study the way in which people cope with their own death. NDEs generally trigger an out-of-body experience into a realm populated with spiritual beings and have the potential to shape American attitudes toward death in general.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Kwilecki | first1 = S | year = 2004 | title = Religion and Coping: A Contribution from Religious Studies | url = | journal = Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion | volume = 43 | issue = 4| pages = 477–489 | doi = 10.1111/j.1468-5906.2004.00250.x }}</ref> Surveys show that five percent of Americans have a NDE, which presents a limited field to study.<ref>Bailey, L. W. and J. Yates. (1996.) Introduction. In the near-death experience: A reader, edited by L. W. Bailey and J. Yates, pp. 1–23. New York: Routledge.</ref> In general, people who have NDEs report positive outcomes including reduced anxiety, increased capacity to love, and a higher sense of meaning and purpose in life.<ref>Atwater, P. M. H. (1994). Beyond the light: The mysteries and revelations of near-death experiences. New York: Avon Books.</ref> Individuals who have NDEs often fall into Pargament's category of transformative coping. In these cases, the person is transformed into a whole new way of life and way of thinking by one supernatural experience.<ref>Pargament, K. I. (1997). The psychology of religion and coping: Theory, research, practice. New York: Guilford Press.</ref>
== Using religious coping in school and work ==
=== MindUP Initiative === Twelve years ago Goldie Hawn founded MindUP: a mindfulness based initiative to help students in schools deal with stress.<ref>Holland, E. (2015, Feb 17). Can 'mindfulness' help students do better in school? advocates say the meditation technique raises focus and lowers stress. critics see religion in disguise. Wall Street Journal (Online)</ref> The program has since been implemented in schools in 28 states, and has locations in Canada, China, Serbia, Australia, and Venezuela. The program invites students to participate in 15 lessons based on neuroscience. Kimberly Schonert-Reichl an employee of MindsUP and of the University of British Columbia evaluated the effectiveness of MindUP on students grades 4 through 5. Her findings are shown below:
* 82% of children reported having a more positive outlook * 81% of children learned to make themselves happy * 58% of children tried to help others more often
Even though MindUP has had very positive effects skeptics call it religion in disguise. They claim that the mindfulness exercises such as "belly breaths" are [[Buddhist]] practices as a different name. In some states MindUP has been removed from schools because schools are supposed to be secular and non-religious.
===Religion as buffer in the workplace=== A study was conducted by Dr Roxane Gervais, a senior psychologist at the Health and Safety Laboratory in Stockport.<ref>Religion forms buffer against work stress. (2014, Jan 09). Telegraph.Co.Uk</ref> She found that people who were more actively religious were more likely to report low levels of anxiety, depression and fatigue and also felt a higher presence of meaning in life. These people also took less sick days. She concluded that employers should accommodate time for employees to engage in religious beliefs while at work in order to improve performance.
==Religious coping in clinical settings== Despite the problems encountered when studying religion as a coping mechanism, much research suggests that using it in intervention settings when applicable may be beneficial. For example, according to a study be Wachholtz and Pargament, when identified religious people suffering from splitting migraines were exposed to meditations with religious or non-religious content, they reported less pain after the religious meditations. Such "psychospiritual" methods have been utilized for a while, although their applications are limited and specific from person to person.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gall|first1=Terry Lynn|last2=Guirguis-Younger|first2=Manal|title=Religious and Spiritual Coping: Current Theory and Research|date=2013|publisher=American Psychology Association|pages=356–357}}</ref>
==Religion vs. spirituality== Research in the psychology of religion often reveals different outcomes between [[religion]] and [[spirituality]]. A person's religion is a collection of belief systems and moral values, often established by a governing institution. Religion is generally more traditional, organized, and sociological. Religion is considered to be more formal and upheld than spirituality.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bryant-Davis|first1=T.|last2=Wong|first2=E. C.|title=Faith to move mountains: Religious coping, spirituality, and interpersonal trauma recovery (2013)|publisher=American Psychologist}}</ref> Spirituality, on the other hand, is a measure of one's intrinsic relationship with their God. Spirituality is viewed and studied as being more free-formed and psychological. Also, spirituality is considered to be a private experience that promotes a process of growing.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bryant-Davis|first1=T.|last2=Wong|first2=E. C.|title=Faith to move mountains: Religious coping, spirituality, and interpersonal trauma recovery (2013)|publisher=American Psychologist}}</ref> In the psychology of coping with trauma, religion and spirituality can play very different roles. Some research shows that religion, but not spirituality can help with coping,<ref>Rees, Tomas. (2012). Religion, but not spirituality, helps protect against post-earthquake trauma. Epiphenom.</ref> whereas other shows that intrinsic spirituality can be a very effective style of coping.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Vespa | first1 = A. | last2 = Jacobsen | first2 = P. B. | last3 = Spazzafumo | first3 = L. | last4 = Balducci | first4 = L. | year = 2011 | title = Evaluation of intrapsychic factors, coping styles, and spirituality of patients affected by tumors | url = | journal = Psycho-Oncology | volume = 20 | issue = 1| pages = 5–11 | doi = 10.1002/pon.1719 | pmid = 20336646 }}</ref> The differences found between religious and spiritual coping may be further evidence of the role of attachment styles and types of coping used. Through religious and spiritual coping, individuals can derive support from a divine being, from other members of a religious congregation, and from making meaning of distressing events, which can lead to the promotion of resilience, healing, and well-being.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bryant-Davis|first1=T.|last2=Wong|first2=E. C.|title=Faith to move mountains: Religious coping, spirituality, and interpersonal trauma recovery (2013)|publisher=American Psychologist}}</ref>
==Problems with studying religious coping== Studying religion as a coping mechanism has proved a difficult task for psychologists. Religion seems to be an integral part of some people's lives but not of others, so specialists cannot be certain whether religion is the variable to study or if there is something about religious people that makes them religious that is worth studying. Many studies only measure the frequency of certain "religious" activities including prayer or religious service attendance; however, just because a person exhibits religious behavior does not mean that he or she uses his or her religion to cope or even adheres to the set of beliefs that constitutes a religion.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ano|first1=Gene|last2=Vasconcelles|first2=Erin|title=Religious Coping and Psychological Adjustment to Stress: A Meta-Analysis|journal=Journal of Clinical Psychology|date=2005|volume=61|issue=4|pages=461–480|doi=10.1002/jclp.20049|pmid=15503316}}</ref>
Much of the research done on religion and coping has been isolated to Christianity. Studies are being conducted to accommodate for the diversity of religions and their differences among cultures.
Many studies on the subject show contrary results. For example, some psychologists conclude that religiosity has no positive or negative outcomes at all and others cite that any form of religious coping has ultimately negative effects. These results may be a product of the inconsistencies in the ways that religion is studied as a coping mechanism or could reflect biases of researchers toward a certain religion.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gall|first1=Terry Lynn|last2=Guirguis-Younger|first2=Manal|title=Religious and Spiritual Coping: Current Theory and Research|date=2013|publisher=American Psychology Association|page=351}}</ref>
